bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Jefferson Randolph Kean, August 27, 1941

div1.p: Kellogg responds to Kean's suggestions concerning the painting “Conquerors of Yellow Fever.” [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Jefferson Randolph Kean, August 27, 1941
div1.opener:
GEORGE A. KELLOGG
257 CORNELISON AVENUE
JERSEY CITY, N.J.
August 27, 1941
Dear General Kean:
div1.p:
Your two letters of August 23 have been much
enjoyed and your advice is much appreciated. I hope that we
are going to be able to mention the names of all the volunteers
in the yellow fever experiments in the key to the painting.

As to the characters in the picture itself I
am following your compromise suggested in using the name of Dr.
Ames and Warren Jernegan at the same time labeling the two heads
which appear much in the background as (14), an anonymous private
representative of the American volunteers, giving all of their
names, and (15) a Spanish representative of the four volunteers
for inoculations, again using the individual names.

I feel that this is a very smart way out of a
difficulty and in this manner we will offend the least possible
number of people.

I just had a letter from Dr. Carlos Finlay, Jr.
this morning in which he apologized for the very hard criticism
which he had made a week or ten days ago. He wrote that he now
regarded putting Dr. Finlay, Sr., and the Yellow Fever Board to-
gether in the same picture was a step in the direction of better
relations between American and Cuban physicians.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, George Kellogg George A. Kellogg
GAK:L
General J. R. Kean
2804 N Street, N. W.,
Washington, D C.
